“SAP schools are racially divisive and hence have no place in the multi-racial Singapore.” Do you agree? Every two or three years, some member of the Parliament will request for the closure of Special Assistance Plan schools, commonly known as SAP schools. SAP schools, which were established in 1979 to preserve the unique culture and traditional values in the Chinese schools, are thought by some to produce racists who discriminated against the other races- the Malays and Indians. While seemingly true, this is not the case. SAP schools are not racially divisive in which this case means to have an effect of separating people into different distinctive groups. Instead, SAP schools have been coming up with comprehensive programmes to inculcate racial harmony in their students. SAP schools still have a role to play in Singapore. Furthermore, students have many opportunities to mix with other races outside school, not merely just in schools. Thus, they do have a place in the multi-racial Singapore. Firstly, SAP schools are putting lots of efforts in coming up with comprehensive programmes to inculcate racial harmony and not produce racists. Besides staple events which every student takes part in, for example the celebration of Racial Harmony Day and Heritage tours, every SAP schools also organise and adopt its own programmes. Several schools have come up with unique programmes which includes the organisation of home visits, multi-racial team games and home stays in which student obtain the chance to live with each other’s families. As SAP schools are aware that they have a largely Chinese population of students, they work a lot harder about this issue than most schools. Some SAP schools have taken the lead in reaching out to the neighbourhood schools- coaching, mentoring and involving them in ethnic festivals, thus ensuring that their students get a chance to interact with the other races. In fact, the only difference is that SAP schools consist of a largely Chinese population while other schools have a god racial mix in their student population. SAP schools are of no difference from any typical schools. What is taught during the curriculum time is similar to that of other schools. SAP schools do what other schools do. The races of population of a school do not affect the students’ mentality towards other races. Just by putting two students of different race together do not ensure racial harmony. It is the students’ attitude towards the other races count. For example, a student who is Malay may come from a typical secondary school but is bias against the Chinese. Hence, the race of the population does not affect greatly the students’ attitude towards the other races. Secondly, SAP schools still have a role to play in the education system of Singapore. SAP schools, through the teaching of English and Chinese both at first-language level, aim to raise Mandarin to first language level alongside English, preserve the Chinese cultural heritage and preserve the valuable environment of the Chinese school system. This allows the younger generation to acquire a deep knowledge of Chinese culture and traditions and ensures that the Chinese traditional values like filial piety, diligence and modesty are being passed on to the next generation. Furthermore, one of the other objectives of SAP schools is to nurture sufficient Chinese elites to engage with China economically and politically. These Chinese elites also serve as “bridges” to connect the Western countries, like the United State of America and the European countries, and other countries like India, which uses English as the main language, with China which uses Mandarin as their main language as these Chinese elites not only have a good command in English but also a full understanding of the Chinese heritage. Thus SAP schools do have a place in the multi-racial Singapore. Lastly, students from SAP schools do have many other opportunities to mix with the other races outside school. Racial harmony is also important outside school, not just merely in schools. Students get a chance to interact with people from other races in places like tuition centres, their workplace when they enter the society and the neighbourhood activities held by the Community Centres or Residents’ Committee. Furthermore, males are entitled to another opportunity- during their National Service. During the National Service, men of different races come together and bond together to understand one another’s culture and way of living. They live together, eat together and sleep together. National Service provides the males a shared experience, which cuts across the barrier of race. SAP schools do not eliminate a student’s chance of interacting with other races, thus letting him grow up to become a racist. There are many other opportunities for him to interact with other races out there .
